description: The underlying cause of the issue described in this post stems from the potential unsecured integration of multiple Copilot components present in Windows 10 and 11 environment configurations. The post highlights that if organizations lack the necessary MS 365 licensing (E3, E5, A3, Business Standard, or Business Premium), there is a significant risk that users may inadvertently expose sensitive or confidential data to Microsoft's large language model (LLM). This is further exacerbated by the lack of administrative controls that can be effectively deployed if the latest Group Policy templates for both Windows 10 22H2 and Windows 11 23H2 are not implemented. Consequently, misconfigurations relating to GPO can leave an organization's intellectual property vulnerable. The reliance on outdated administrative templates limits the availability of necessary security policies, contributing to the overall risk assessment of using innovative features like Copilot without properly managing data exposure.
